Speaker.P: The answer to (a) is the 26th June, 1964.

With regard to (b) it is not possible to give a precise date. I can only repeat what I have already said in reply to previous questions that the drafting of regulations is proceeding with the best possible speed, taking into account the comprehensive nature of the recommendations and the highly complex nature of the drafting.

MainHeading.P: I would, however, point out that in November, 1966, regulations entitled Medical Preparations (Control of Sale) Regulations, 1966, were enacted which restricted to pharmacists, etc., and then only on prescription the sale of a very large range of medical preparations containing substances recommended by Comhairle na Nimheanna for control.
The regulations now being drafted will replace these regulations and effect further controls.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that there are six drugs of addiction freely available without prescription?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: No.
Is the Minister aware that they were not covered by the regulations of February, 1966? They are not included in them. I sent details of these to his Department some months ago.
asked the Minister for Health if he will take steps to bring the sale of methedrine under control and to curb the right to prescribe it by private doctors.
asked the Minister for Health if he will consider setting up a committee to investigate sales of amphetamines with a view to bringing this drug under control.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 56 and 57 together.

The retail sale of amphetamines, including methedrine, is already controlled under the Medical Preparations (Control of Sale) Regulations, 1966, which provide that the substances in question may not be sold to the public by persons other than pharmaceutical chemists, dispensing chemists and druggists and registered druggists and may not be dispensed except on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner, dentist or veterinary surgeon. As I have already indicated in reply to previous questions, and in a recent press statement, I propose to strengthen the existing powers of control by making the unauthorised possession of such substances a punishable offence.

MainHeading.P: As regards the Deputy's suggestion that I should take steps to curb the right of private medical practitioners to prescribe methedrine, it would be a serious step to interfere with the right of a doctor to prescribe the drug of his choice for a patient.

Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that certain rules have been suggested to the authorities in Britain to deal with these two drugs and that high medical opinion holds that neither of these drugs is strictly necessary to the practice of good medicine?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: There appear to be varying views on this. The Irish Medical Association were consulted. They were against the idea of banning the drug altogether.
asked the Minister for Health if he has a record of the sales of heroin in this country; and how much of it was imported last year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: The total amount of heroin imported into this country in 1967 was 174 grammes—6 ozs approx.
This was used in minute quantities in the preparation of medicines for sale on prescription by retail chemists. Records are not available in my Department of the individual prescriptions.
That is the legal importation?

Would the Minister not think it well that this commodity should be brought under more strict control as there are reports widespread in Britain that it is being exported illegally from here. Arising from this, it may be accepted that some of it might find its way in here through unorthodox channels.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I appreciate this. I have no doubt at all that unfortunately a certain amount of this drug is coming into this country illegally. The information I have given relates to the legal purchase of heroin.
Is there any truth in the report that Ireland is being used as a base for the illegal importation and re-export of heroin to Britain?
The Deputy is nothing if not sensational.
That has been reported. Deputy Carter asked the same question in other words.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. James Tully Mr. James Tully
Speaker.P: Let Deputy Carter and Deputy L'Estrange both give whatever information they have to the police.
I did so. I gave my information to the Commissioner of the Garda Síochána——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: It is the duty of everybody concerned with the public welfare, whether in this House or outside it, forthwith to give to the police, to me or to the Minister for Justice any information, however tenuous it might be, immediately.
I went to the Commissioner of the Police three years ago with any information I had. I gave it to him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I would expect the Deputy would be responsible enough to do that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Register of Drug Addicts.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will take steps to prepare a register of drug addicts; and if he will have a proper identity card issued to each addict.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: From the information available to me, I do not consider that I would be warranted in taking the steps suggested by the Deputy at present. I am keeping the question of the abuse of drugs under constant review.
One is glad to hear——
Has the Deputy a supplementary question to put to the Minister?
No. 59: I am seeking supplementary information on Question No. 59.
But the Deputy must ask a question.
Yes. The Minister is aware, of course——
That is not a question.
The Minister will be aware—just a moment, if you please——
“Is he aware.”

Sorry: is the Minister aware—if the Chair would bring Deputy L'Estrange under control, one might be able to concentrate; it is not a matter for levity and the Deputy is treating these questions with some levity——
Let us get back to the question.

Is the Minister aware that elsewhere steps have been taken to keep a case history of each drug addict and would he not consider that such a system should be adopted here? Would he not also agree that this procedure would be in the best interests of preventive medicine?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: Deputy Carter is using the word “addict” loosely. In the Mental Treatment Acts, an addict is defined as a person:

who by reason of his addiction to drugs or intoxicants is either dangerous to himself or others or incapable of managing himself or his affairs or of ordinary proper conduct or by reason of his addiction to drugs, intoxicants or perverted conduct is in serious danger of mental disorder.
The number of people involved here would be quite small and it is not apparent what purpose would be served by keeping such a record.

Is the Minister aware that there is a considerable number of drug addicts who are not known to his Department because he has no register? These people are in need of help and by having their names on a register, they would get a continuation of their drugs by normal means and not by every subterfuge known to them to get drugs from doctors and pharmacists. I would appeal to the Minister seriously to consider the setting up of a drug register for this purpose.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Control of Drugs.

Speaker.hpid: Sir Anthony Esmonde Sir Anthony Esmonde
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the earliest date on which he hopes to introduce legislation to control dangerous drugs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I presume that the Deputy is aware of the existing statutory controls which apply to certain drugs, under the Dangerous Drugs Act, 1934, and the Medical Preparations (Control of Sale) Regulations, 1966, and I take it that his question relates to the proposed measures to deal with the unauthorised possession of what are generally termed “soft” drugs (amphetamines, barbiturates, LSD etc.).
I hope to introduce legislation next autumn.
Did the Minister read what was in the Journal of the Irish Medical Association?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Thalidomide Deformities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will release the full report of the survey conducted into the incidence of thalidomide-induced deformities in Ireland; and if he will also release the follow-up report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: The report on the survey of limb deformities which might be attributable to the use of thalidomide was in the form of a series of tables which included the incidence of certain congenital defects by counties, and contained clinical details of the precise nature of the defects. As it might be possible to identify individual cases from the data shown it would not, in my opinion, be in the public interest to release it. The situation disclosed by the report has, of course, been made public, through information given on the 4th June, 1964 on the introduction of the Estimate for the Department of Health for 1964-65 and in reply to a number of Parliamentary Questions.

The primary object of the follow-up report was to establish whether the incidence of congenital abnormalities returned to the earlier level after the withdrawal of thalidomide. The report showed inter alia that it had done so.

Is the Minister aware that every clinical report could identify the subjects and not necessarily this one? I do not think his explanation is good enough. It is a very lame excuse for not publishing the report, which is a very important one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I do not agree with the Deputy.
The whole purpose of the survey was that it be published.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Incidence of Arthritis.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if any survey has been carried out into the incidence of disabling arthritic conditions in Ireland, the facilities available for research into these conditions, the actual research being carried out and the rehabilitation service available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: No comprehensive survey of the incidence of disabling arthritic conditions has been carried out in this country. I have asked the Medico-Social Research Board to carry out a continuing hospital inpatient survey and this should provide information in relation to the patients suffering from these conditions who are admitted to hospital. The Medical Research Council provides funds to assist research projects which they regard as being worthy of support and they would be in a position to consider research proposals in relation to arthritic conditions. The Dublin Rheumatism Clinic would also be in a position to provide facilities for worthwhile research in the Dublin area. The Clinic carries out studies as to the effectiveness of new drugs in association with the drug manufacturers but I am not aware of any other specific research proceeding in this country at present. The National Rehabilitation Board in association with the National Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Dún Laoghaire and with the various voluntary organisations working for the disabled has a responsibility for organising the rehabilitation both medical and vocational of those disabled by arthritic conditions. I should, of course, add that a great deal of work in terms of treatment and reactivation is carried on for these patients in the general and orthopaedic hospitals.

Is the Minister aware that quite a considerable number of working days are lost due to these disabling arthritic conditions and research into the problem would save the country a tremendous amount of money?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I am certainly aware of the loss of working days.

Might we assume that the Rheumatism Clinic, which operate under the direct control of the Minister's Department, would consider as part of their functions to keep abreast of current literature on research proceeding abroad into rheumatoid arthritis and allied conditions?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I am sure they do.

Is the Minister aware that sometimes these institutions which we set up start off with a wide spectrum of interest and then in their desire to cure people, allow it to narrow somewhat at the cost of research?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: There is a team working in England at the moment and the Clinic are considering having that team over here to carry out a similar survey.

Perhaps the Minister's attention has been drawn to a claim originating in New York or London of a recent rather remarkable breakthrough in the possibility of treating rheumatoid arthritis to which perhaps the attention of the Clinic might be directed for evaluation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I have not seen it but I will bring the Deputy's remarks to their attention.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Foster Homes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if his attention has been drawn to a report of the annual general meeting of the Infant Aid Society held in Dublin last week if; in view of this report he will instruct all local authorities to take immediate steps to find foster homes by seeking the assistance of foster parents; and if he will instruct local authorities to bring their boarded out allowances into line with present day demands.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: My attention has been drawn to the report referred to by the Deputy. Health authorities generally are well aware that it has always been the policy of my Department to encourage them to board-out children to the greatest possible extent. They advertise regularly for foster parents in the public press and they also make contact with prospective foster parents through their own officers and others interested in the welfare of children.
The amount of allowances payable to foster parents is a matter to be decided by each health authority and I am aware that a number of authorities have increased their allowances in recent months.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Autistic Children.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health what steps his Department are taking to obtain an assessment in each health authority of the number of autistic children as distinct from mentally deficient children; and what general scheme he proposes to initiate in respect of autistic children.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: As I have indicated in replies to previous questions in the matter, there is no generally accepted definition of autism in children. The term is used to describe a particular illness but it is also used to cover a number of different mental illnesses of childhood. At present statistics of the total number of children in this country in need of psychiatric care are not available, and, indeed, reliable statistics are not available for any country. Children from any health authority area may be referred to centres in Dublin and Cork for assessment.

There is a residential unit of 30 beds for mentally ill children, including autistic children, at St. Loman's Hospital, Ballyowen, County Dublin, and a day-centre for such children at St. Kevin's Hospital, Dublin. Tenders have been invited for the building of a further unit in Dublin. The possibility of obtaining a suitable building for a unit in Cork is being investigated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if his attention has been drawn to a booklet issued by the Canadian Government dealing with parent guidance etc. in respect of autistic children; and if he will have a similar booklet issued by his Department so that valuable information on this matter may reach the parents of such children in this country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I am not aware of any booklet issued by the Canadian Government, but the Deputy is possibly referring to a booklet issued by the Canadian Mental Health Association. If this is so, copies of the booklet have already been distributed by The Irish Society for Autistic Children. Any interested person may obtain a copy from the Society. I see no need for my Department to issue a similar booklet.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mental Handicap.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when he will publish a White Paper on the report of the Commission on Mental Handicap; and if, having regard to the urgency of the matter, he will now outline what progress will be made during the next five years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: I hope to be in a position to publish a White Paper on the services for the mentally handicapped in a few months time. The White Paper will set out in full the Government's decision in regard to the various recommendations of the Commission, but the development of services is not being held up pending the publication of the White Paper. As I pointed out to the House on the 6th instant the services are being continually developed, considerable improvements have been brought about since the report of the Commission was published, and it is the Government's intention to press ahead with the developments as rapidly as circumstances and resources will permit.

asked the Minister for Health the reason for the delay in giving approval to the proposal of Dublin Health Authority to make premises at Cherry Orchard Hospital available to the National Association for the Mentally Handicapped together with a grant towards the cost of operating the centre; and if he will expedite favourable consideration of the proposal having regard to the urgent need for additional accommodation and facilities for the mentally handicapped.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: The delay in this case was caused by the need to consider whether the National Association for the Mentally Handicapped of Ireland was the most appropriate body to provide sheltered workshops and how the proposal would fit in with other proposals which I have received. I have now directed that the proposal of the Dublin Health Authority to lease the premises should be approved. I will also approve the making of a contribution towards the running costs of the centre.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Sligo Farm Purchase.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware that a farm (particulars supplied) in County Sligo is being purchased by a businessman who lives eight miles from it; and if he will prevent the completion of this sale with a view to having the lands in question acquired by the Land Commission for distribution amongst uneconomic holders in the locality.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Lands (Mr. Faulkner) Minister for Lands (Mr. Faulkner)
Speaker.P: I am aware that there has been a sale of this farm; I am also advised that the transaction was later the subject of court proceedings and the Circuit Court in May last confirmed the sale. The Land Commission have no proceedings for the acquisition of the lands.

Is the Minister aware of the position in my constituency in relation to the Land Commission? Is he aware that business and professional people are buying up land all over the place, as far away as eight miles from their places of residence in some cases, and I wonder is it in conformity with the rules of the Land Commission to allow such purchases? Is the Minister further aware that the small farmer in the West is being virtually squeezed out of existence because, due to lack of capital, he cannot compete with those wealthier people?

As I have already pointed out to the Deputy, this matter was the subject of court proceedings in the Circuit Court and my information is that in that particular area, congestion is not very acute; there is a holding at present on offer to the Land Commission which, if acquired, will satisfy the requirements of the local people.
Is the Minister aware that the purchaser of this land is a businessman who lives eight miles from the farm? Is he aware that court proceedings will not be finalised until 1st July?

Question No. 69.
Would the Minister say if he is prepared to allow business people to buy land eight miles from their places of residence when there are small uneconomic holders in the area?
That is a separate question.
I have already explained to the Deputy that there is a farm on offer to the Land Commission and, if it is purchased, it will satisfy the requirements of the small farmers in the area.
Is the Minister aware——
I am calling Question No. 69. We cannot debate this question all evening.
Is the Minister aware that I have a farm on offer to the Land Commission for the past 12 months and I have heard nothing yet?
If the Deputy will give me the particulars, I will have the matter inquired into.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Wexford Forestry Land.

Speaker.hpid: Sir Anthony Esmonde Sir Anthony Esmonde
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands the amount of land held by the Forestry Branch of his Department in County Wexford; the pool of land available for future planting; and if such a pool guarantees full maintenance of present employment.

The total productive area held by the Forestry Division of my Department in County Wexford on 31st March, 1968 was 19,098 acres of which 16,612 acres were under woods and plantations leaving a reserve of 2,486 acres nominally available for planting. The extent of the plantable reserve is only one of the factors influencing employment and any given level of plantable reserve could not of itself be regarded as affording a guarantee of maintaining employment.

Speaker.hpid: Sir Anthony Esmonde Sir Anthony Esmonde
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give a guarantee that those who are at present employed in forestry in County Wexford will have continuity of employment?

I have already explained to the Deputy, in reply to a specific question he put down, that the extent of the plantable reserve is only one factor and it cannot be taken on its own as affording a guarantee of retaining employment.

Speaker.hpid: Sir Anthony Esmonde Sir Anthony Esmonde
Speaker.P: Could the Minister help me by telling me what the other factors are?
Some of the factors which affect employment are the increased use of machinery and the increased use of chemicals: they are factors.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. James Tully Mr. James Tully
Speaker.P: Shortage of money?
No, not shortage of money. The ones I have mentioned are the principal factors, I would say. We are endeavouring to acquire more land under a new price structure which will, I hope, be successful.

Speaker.hpid: Sir Anthony Esmonde Sir Anthony Esmonde
Speaker.P: I appreciate the Minister's answer, but he will note from my question that I am endeavouring to find out if there is likely to be continuity of employment for those presently employed and can he give me a reassuring reply to that question?
He cannot.
I will do my utmost to ensure this but it is a difficult matter and I cannot give a specific answer.
They may emigrate to England.
